+The Phoenix Sorry you had to go through that. Unfortunately, the US 
Supreme Court ruled that police can legally lie all they want, including 
lying about arresting you if you don't give permission to search. I hope 
you checked out some other videos here on yt that talk about how to deal 
with police when they threaten to arrest you if you don't consent. FYI, one 
exception to the requirement that they have your permission to legally 
search your vehicle is called the Plain View Doctrine. If you have any 
illegal contraband in plain view when the officer looks into your vehicle, 
they can legally reach in to seize it as evidence of a crime, without a 
warrant and without your permission, and also seize anything else that 
comes into view while reaching in to take the first item. Short of that, 
they need your permission or probable cause or a warrant. If the police 
have any of those things, they don't need your permission to search. They 
only ask for your permission because they otherwise have nothing, and as I 
am sure you already know, once you give permission, you don't have a leg to 
stand on. Better luck to you in the future.

+BlueDrakilicious You know you're so right. And here's the thing I am by no 
means, idk what to call it, pro-cop? Nor am I anti-cop though, and this is 
coming from a guy that's been on the wrong side of the law more times than 
I care to admit, BUT as I've gotten older and matured I've realized the 
importance of their role in our society AND I've also come to understand 
that in order for them to do their job there will occasionally be the 
innocent person that gets harassed. !t's like I said in a previous comment 
we "have to take the good with the bad" and sometimes there will be some 
collateral damage. The thing that gets me though, is when you get these 
naive children that think what they saw in a movie or heard online is REAL! 
And that they're going to express their rights and not "lay down" for these 
dirty cops, when almost NONE of them have ANY 1st hand knowledge of their 
"Rights" let alone how easily those "rights" get dismissed when you're 
dealing with the police. Anyway the bottom line is this if you're not doing 
anything wrong than who cares if they want to see some ID? If I feel like 
I've been "profiled" and stopped or approached for no reason, yea it might 
be an inconvenience, but you know what, I'm GLAD they did it! That tells me 
that they're doing their fkn job! If your going to take my hard earned 
money to pay these muthafuckers, then Godammit I want to see them WORK! 
lol! Seriously though, I understand why a lot of ppl feel the way they do, 
I used to feel the same way! So I educated myself on what our rights are as 
citizens, and what the laws are surrounding those rights, what the laws are 
governing the police, and how a lot of these laws vary from state to 
state... And then the MOST important thing I learned (via real life 
experiences) was how EASILY those rights/laws were manipulated by the cops, 
judges, attorneys, probation/parole officers, (the list goes on...) to fit 
THEIR AGENDA. And how ALL of them play for the same team! They're all in 
cahoots! Which makes it that much more difficult to express OUR rights or 
PROVE a violation therein! Anyway, I'm getting off track, I've grown up 
 since then, I had a child.... My perspective CHANGED dramatically. I 
stopped being a law breaker and became a law abider. I began to recognize 
the difficulty of upholding the law and the immense pressure that the 
police in our country are under... I gained a new level of respect for the 
men and women that do it. Don't get me wrong I always respected the cops 
but it was the kind of respect that you have for an enemy, or a worthy 
adversary, and of course some earned more than others. But this newfound 
respect was truly warranted. And with it I realized this: I'd rather suffer 
the inconvenience of being profiled and asked for my ID and KNOW that 
they're out there keeping my neighborhood safe for my kids, than to never 
be bothered and feel the complete opposite. To feel like they're not doing 
shit and know that the criminals in my neighborhood feel the same way. If 
the cops aren't doing their job then it's open season for the "bad guys". I 
grew up in a neighborhood just like that, the cops wanted NO PARTS. They 
only came in to protect the paramedics or the coroner while they scooped up 
the bodies. Oh and to protect the firemen when they had to come in. Other 
than that; you'd never even see them. And what do you think the "bad guys" 
did?....They did WHATEVER THE FCK THEY WANTED TO! I don't want my children 
to grow up that way. And if that means suffering the occasional indecency 
of BS traffic stop or a pat-down and ID check because of my appearance, 
then so be it. Cause there really is no happy medium. You can't have both; 
you can't have cops that never violate ppl's rights AND cops that prevent 
crime... It's not possible. And if anyone out there can figure out a way to 
accomplish that, plz reply asap because I would love to hear it.

Your comments show just how completely out of touch you are with the 
situation.

1) This is not a junior officer and supervisor as you noted. These are two 
different law enforcement agencies completely. A State Trooper, the person 
you labeled as a supervisor, pulled you over and requested a K9 to his 
location because he suspected you of holding illegal drugs. The K9 handler, 
the person you labeled as the junior officer, showed up to conduct the 
search with his dog. It appears the handler is a Sheriff's Deputy. The 
other Deputy you see in the video is a sergeant from the handler's agency.

2) How in the world do you know if the dog did or did not indicate on 
illegal drugs in the vehicle?? Are you trained in K9 searches? Do you know 
what to look for when a K9 actually hits on illegal drugs? The dog 
typically just sits when he finds illegal drugs. The dog doesn't grab the 
drugs in his mouth and trots over to the handler. After The dog indicates 
he found illegal drugs, the dog is put away and the handler and primary 
officer conducts the search. The supreme court has ruled a hit by a K9 is 
sufficient cause to search a vehicle.

3) Again, these are law enforcement officers from two different 
jurisdictions. The K9 Handler was assisting the Trooper. The K9 Handler 
found your marijuana and informed the Trooper of the discovery and 
location. The Trooper then went to the location and collected the marijuana 
for a fluid chain of custody on the marijuana. This is pretty apparent 
because after the handler talks to the trooper, he walks to his car and 
gets a plastic baggie and a NiK kit. Then walks to where the handler was 
searching. It is unknown if this is true because its not in the video, but 
my guess is the dog sat in the exact location the handler was searching. 

4) Criminal charges are often dropped on guilty persons by the District 
Attorney for a variety of reasons. They may have determined that the crime 
that occurred wasn't worth the time it would take for prosecution. 

You got caught with marijuana, you were charged because it was in the area 
you were sitting. It's hilarious that so many people are completely 
ignorant on believing your lies.﻿

madmen. It is monstrous if the state fails to protect its residents... but

There are spoilers and there are wings.
This car has a wing.
Wings are intended to improve cornering traction by creating downforce on 
the wheels. And yes they do increase drag.
Spoilers are curved up surfaces usually on a trunk lid that create 
turbulence behind a vehicle. Airflow passing over the car then strikes the 
roiling turbulent air behind the spoiler rather than sticking to the 
boundary layer and sucking down behind the car. This reduces the low 
pressure area behind the car which then reduces drag.

+El Hombre Not really, what you mentioned is a use of spoilers, spoilers 
are made to create downforce to make RWD cars or 4WD cars get grip onto the 
rear tires, helps them go faster and safer into corners, useful safety wise 
if you for e.g. Have to turn sharply on the freeway to avoid an unexpected 
crash or something like that

+Black Rabbit spoilers are used for cars that go really fast. The purpose 
of them is to prevent a car from taking flight while going 250+ mph. That 
car probably is limited at 100 mph, so the spoiler is doubly pointless.

+Bills By Vexa You don't need a search warrant for a car.  All you need is 
probable cause.  It has been that way since the Prohibition Era.  There are 
MANY court cases about search and seizure of cars.  Basically, the SCOTUS 
has ruled that cars DRIVEN on public roads don't have the same expectation 
of privacy as homes.  Interestingly, parked cars are protected differently 
than being pulled over.  It's actually more likely the car will be searched 
on-site.  There are issues involved with waiting too long to conduct the 
search...MANY cases as well.

+jimmi izzy the if cops needed a warrant for all searches theyd need a 
warrant for all arrests too since searches AND seizures are illegal without 
probable cause. All warrantless searches and seizures are double checked by 
the same person who would issue the warrant anyway. Cops know this. 
Therefore, if a cop goes out and conducts warrantless searches without 
probable cause they will be denied the the legality of their search, no 
charges filed, no entry into jail for their arrestee and then face the 
possibility of being sued for unlawful arrest. A cop absolutely has the 
authority to determine if probable cause exisits on a traffic stop and to 
conduct a warrantless search based on that probable cause because of the 
Carroll Doctrine. The same cannot be said for a residence because a 
residence doesnt generally have any mobile conveyance thus would not fall 
under one of the exemptions for a warrantless search and therefore require 
a warrant prior to a search being carried out. A cop cant do whatever he 
wants and just haul people to jail unquestioned and without being 
doublechecked and checked again all throughout the process. If it is 
determined that they are out conducting warrantless searches or seizures 
that problem corrects itself in the form of civil suits against the cop 
where they can potentially lose everything...house and all. So, every 
encounter a police officer has with joe snuffy on the street and every 
decision made by that officer towards joe snuffy puts their whole career 
and peraonal life and livelihood on the line. Thats a tremendous amount of 
responsibility. Arresting or charging some kid for dope he doesnt have is 
not worth losing everything because the cop is shady. Would you stake your 
career, home, everything else you own and your family's wellbeing on a 
misdemeanor dope charge for some ahole driving around looking at rental

https://www.law.cornell.edu/wex/Fourth_amendment

My understanding is that in order to conduct a lawful search, consent must 
be granted or a warrant must be issued by a magistrate. The dog hit could 
be used as probable cause, but that cause must be presented to the judge 
and the warrant must be issued. A warrant can be by-passed in special 
circumstances such as when the police are in fear that the evidence may be 
destroyed or things like that. But to my knowledge, a dog cannot issue a 
warrant, and an officer thinking he has probable cause doesn't by-pass the 
requirement of the law to obtain a warrant. If it were true that a search 
could be conducted whenever an officer thinks he or she has probable cause, 
then why would they ever need to get a warrant? In every circumstance, they 
could just state their bullshit probable cause and just search away. But 
that is not the case, and that is why they obtain warrants, because they 
have to in order for the evidence to be permissible in court. 

I think what has happened is that they have fooled people into thinking 
that they can search whenever they want because they have said so and done 
it for so long. People, for some reason, believe them. So now they can just 
have a dog do some baloney signal, and people think that they have lost 
their 4th amendment protection.

What probably happened: Cop in an unmarked police car see a sketchy car 
with heavy tinted windows rolling slowly through a rural neighborhood. See 
it as suspicious (and it is) and pull you over. In 99% of cases such a stop 
results in actually finding something illegal because it seems a lot of 
criminals don't use their heads (maybe it's the drugs?). After that point 
however the cops stepped out of line IF they did indeed plant something. We 
can't really tell since you didn't show the video of the K9 search. For all 
we (internet viewers) know is the K9 got a hit and the search resulted from 
that and not you giving consent. Not saying you're a liar but I don't know 
you. You are in a suspicious car and were acting suspiciously from your own 
testimony. You could be telling the truth but maybe not. As some others 
have said, if you went for a drug test the very next day and it came back 
clean (the both of you) then you would have strong enough evidence that the 
drug was planted. No trafficker will have a small morsel of anything. Only 
a user would. If no drug was found in the system (considering pot lingers) 
the next day, clearly that nugget shouldn't have been there. Such tests 
wouldn't prove the cops planted anything but would prove you two likely 
didn't put it there. The next line of investigation would be to find out 
who has sat in that passenger seat over the last month or so (prior to the 
stop). Are any of them drug users? Believe it or not, a lot of people use 
pot. Some are stupid enough to bring some in a car. Some are even stupid 
enough to bring it in a friends car. Doesn't matter who put it there, if 
found by the police, whoever is sitting closest to it gets the charge.

As for the charge being dismissed, it's entirely possible it was because it 
was such a small amount and not worth the prosecutors time. Usually when 
corrupt cops plant something, they plant enough of something to promise a 
prosecution. Pot is not a good drug to plant since in modern times most pot 
cases involving small amounts are thrown out. Cocaine or meth would be a 
better drug to plant. Small, not a lot of/no odor, easily concealed, and 
typically brings a prosecution.

I can understand your frustration IF you two are indeed innocent, but just 
because you are innocent doesn't mean the cops planted it. Just because you 
show some of the scene on video doesn't mean the situation leading up to 
the event is as you described.

On a side note, when a cop finds something, they typically don't move it 
right away. They will go back to their cruiser to get an evidence bag and 
any test kit they need to verify if what they found is what they think it 
is. If the test shows it is, the bag it. I seen nothing out of order in 
this video. However they did spend an excessive amount of time on the stop. 
The only way they would be legally justified in such a long stop is if the 
drug dog signaled. At that point they know there is something there and 
will search till they find it even if it takes all day.﻿

Brian I get you buddy, but not all searches are legal under certain 
conditions. Alcohol and Weed are two that will definitely get you jammed 
up, but if you play your cards right you'll be fine. Don't do anything 
stupid and never ever trust these guys by giving consent. The following is 
a list of how cops can search your vehicle. 

1. If you give consent.

2. If something is in plain view like drugs or  weapons which wasn't the 
case here.

3. Search incident to arrest, I don't think these folks got arrested and 
every arrest doesn't warrant a search. For example if an officer arrested 
me for reckless driving that doesn't constitute a search of my vehicle, 
just my person. They'd tow my car and do a inventory at the station and 
what that allows is the protection of the officers and the person getting 
arrested. It ensures that officers aren't placing things in your car and it 
ensure that they don't have you on the road for too long. Also its a case 
by case bases on the time limit an officer can keep you on the road after 
the initial reason and citation for a stop. 

A cop can't issue you a ticket for a broken tailight, and decide on his way 
back that he smells weed. Wait an unreasonable amount of time for a K9 and 
then expect it to uphold in court. Traffic stops are considered a 
detainment and seizure until you're free to go... An unreasonable search 
and seizure would not fly in court.

4. Probable cause, If it looks like a duck and walks/quack/flies etc like a 
duck, it is a duck. If you've got blood all over your hands and seats and 
the trunk area the officer is going to be pretty suspicious. You can 
politely decline a search and seizure, but you better believe the cadaver 
dogs are on the way. Btw, these dogs are a way around the 4th amendment.

5. Exigent circumstances, this will probably  never happen during traffic 
stops and it most commonly occurs when searching houses etc. Exigent 
circumstances allows an officer to search your car in the event that he 
thinks evidence will be destroyed. However, cars are considered mobile 
objects and that gives an officer the right to search if he really has a 
hunch that criminal activity is afoot.

I've been advised by several counsel that if pulled over or stopped by the 
police for any reason, turn on the overhead light, show your hands, do not 
get out of the vehicle, keep your doors locked, do not make any sudden 
movements, and do not say anything except hello. Do not hand over anything 
except a special card with the following text.
“This interaction is NOT consensual, and is being audio and video recorded 
for my safety as well as yours. On the advice of counsel, I am invoking my 
Fourth Amendment rights and do NOT consent to ANY searches of my person or 
property. I furthermore invoke my Fifth Amendment rights and refuse to 
answer ANY questions. Please do NOT ask me any questions without my legal 
counsel present!” If pressed, start singing the National Anthem or the song 
Cuban Pete;;)

You may present your driver’s license or id against the window, but do not 
hand it over, if you submit the license or id you may not get it back for a 
very long time and don’t leave without it. Continue to ask if you are being 
detained, for what reason, and when are you free to go. It’s a good idea to 
have photocopies of registration, license, insurance, statutes, list of 
contacts, Star-Spangled Banner, etc. handy and ready. It’s not an admission 
of guilt to sign a citation to appear. Protect yourself! Install a dash cam 
and learn to use the video function of your iphone.
Familiarize yourself with local state laws about police stops. Stop and 
frisk laws allow police to briefly detain and ask for names (if they have 
reasonable suspicion and probable cause to suspect a crime) and, if 
warranted, to pat for weapons - that's it - nothing more. A stop doesn’t 
necessarily justify a frisk.
You may be innocent but what of any passengers? The police will try to 
bully and lie if they can, be polite but firm! A favorite bogus tactic is 
to lie and say that they saw something in plain sight, so take pictures - 
lots of them! Another favorite bogosity is to threaten with obstruction for 
resisting by not answering questions, don't fall for it! If you’re arrested 
for such then you got grounds for a lawsuit. Don’t argue! If they want to 
argue just give them your counselor’s phone number!
If you are being arrested then cooperate, but say that you wish to remain 
silent until you’ve been given legal counsel. Try to get every officer at 
the scene name and badge number, also any K9 certifications. Roll up the 
windows and lock the doors. Lock away your iphone.
The police are not your friends; they will arrest you for any reason 
whatsoever, real or imagined. They will seize your vehicle and property and 
force a forfeiture.
Obey the law, no matter how asinine it may be!﻿
